Posts.Content: Had my prostatectomy 5.4.18. Gleason 6 became Gleason 7 (3+4). All margins, nodes etc were negative. Had my psa 6 weeks after surgery result was <.03. The one resident on hospital said there may be some residual psa for 6 to 8 weeks then go to zero. surgeon expected a zero today. Is there normally a residual psa? should I be concerned about <.03? some websites considered this non-dectable others said it was detectable. I don't believe it was the ultra sensitive psa test. Any ideas appreciated. Thanks. As a footnote I was the person with the surgeon that suggested a partial prostatectomy since it was an anterior tumor. I had the complete prostatectomy not partial. Turns our there were 4 or 5 areas of cancer in my prostate. It comprised about 10% of prostate and grade 4 was 1 to 10%. glad I didn't get the partial. Makes me question the radiation seeds etc if you can have multiple areas that don't show up on an MRI. Treat one area and the rest grow. Thanks again
Posts.Title: 6wks Post Ralp PSA result

Posts.Content: Davinci prostatectomy 5.4.18. first psa 5 weeks later <0.03. Test this week 0.04. I know there could be residual tissue and I know there could be lab errors (test done in same hospital)but the increase is very concerning to me. Wondering if the entire effort for a cure was worth it. Any advice appreciated.
Posts.Title: Well, Now What?

Posts.Content: Thanks for the comments. I will try to post my stats, biopsy results etc this week. Basically 97gm prostate , 10 % of prostate involved. preop Gleason 3+3 . Biopsy after 3+4 with less than 10% grade 4. Multiple areas of prostate involved. No seen spreading on biopsy after surgery. Nothing in 5 or 6 lymph nodes, no extraprostatic, seminal vesicules or margins involved. Seemed to be a very clean, so to speak, biopsy or prostate removed. MD appoint this week so I will see what he says but I expect it will be retest in 3 months. There are so many articles with various recommendations. From do noting unless psa over 0.2 or 0.1 or 3 increases or..... Heck there are articles that list what is undectable until you go to the next article and the next and so on. Doesn't seem to any cut and dry answer with it. Still not really sure what is correct. I did not read the self pity posting because I don't think I am pitying myself. I had stage one colon cancer surgery about 7 years ago and I THINK I got away without it spreading. Did the dance with CEA results from <.5 to creeping up to 1 a year of so after surgery and back down to 0.5 for several years now. That diagnosis was much tougher for me than this. Sometimes it frustrating to try to everything you can and just not having it work as it should. Also, I know of several people that have been diagnosed with different types of cancer from prostate, throat lung etc. Really great people. They went through all the chemo, radiation, special diets recommended by loved ones etc. Some have passed on others look like walking rag dolls. shadows of their former selves. sometimes hard to figure out what treatment is worthwhile and what is not. So I guess I just want to say I do not pity myself its just hard to understand at times. Thanks for the support and I am glad you guys are there.

Posts.Title: Well, Now What?

Posts.Content: Is it right for me. Yes I think so. My concern is the possibility of permanent incontinence. Radiation carries the same risks. If my prostate was small,normal size, I would probalby go with radiation. My prostate being large causes some dribbling, stress incontinence etc now that has gotten worse as I age. I am hopeful that the surgery will remove the cancer but also some of the incontinence issues I have currently. Only scary part is if the incontinence becomes worse and stays that way. I don't think there are other options unless I am missing something.
Posts.Title: My Story and decision time

Posts.Content: My prostate is large, about 100cc, and over the years has caused the normal incontinence issues. Dribbling after urination, stress incontinence, multiple trips to the bathroom at night etc. I am overweight also which I know does not help. After several years of going to a urologist who monitors his patient with a DRE and psa test. Psa had been rising and his response had always been "you have a large prostate but there are no areas that are suspect". Psa gradually increased to 8 or 9. He did a biopsy and found only some ASAP cells which he felt were nothing. Then Psa spike to 15 for unknown reason that forced him into order an MRI which showed a suspect area. Having my fill of this doctor I went to a highly rated large hospital and got a urology surgeon that specializes in robotic surgery. Seems very competent and expierenced. Did a psa there and it was 9.66. He did a mri fusion biopsy and took several cores from the tumor which is anterior rather than posterior(which is why the first doctor could not find it with a DRE). Gleason 6 although the cores were 70 to 80% cancer. But if you consider is was fusion guided and several cores were done there I feel pretty confident it is gleason 6. Tried AS for 6 months. Latest psa 11.5. Have at this point decided on surgery. They are doing a new type of surgery called a partial prostatectomy. Only used on those with anterior tumors. They remove the front of the prostate and recconect the bladder. Idea behind this surgery is he does not go any where near the nerves so there should not be any damage to them. Has anyone heard of this type of surgery good or bad? I am really tired of the current frequency and incontinence from the large prostate I am willing to try anything. I am hoping the surgery will help with the current incontinence. Opinions for or against. Do most people gain control after surgery after a period of time? Dont know whether to opt for traditional remove it all surgery or try this new type. Any help or comments appreciated.
Posts.Title: My Story and decision time

Posts.Content: Thank you for the reply. I did see the study you referenced which gives me pause and concern. He has done less than 20 of these since it is new at that institution(he is the one bringing to that hospital) but has done many robotic surgeries for bladder, kidney, prostrate cancer etc. I feel he is very competent. I did have a consult there with radiation oncology department. Prostate to large for seeds. said they could do Sbrt or Imrt if I wanted but this would not correct the size of prostate and incontinence connected to it. They would help me if I wanted but they thought surgery was best. I did have genetic testing done and was considered intermediate grade. Psa 10. clinical grade T1c, max tumor involvement in any one core >50%. Prostate volume 97. Psa density .10. Listed as one positive core although with the fusion guided biopsy I believe he took several in tumor. Results from Oncotype Dx was GPS 19=favorable intermediate risk. I would have to have another MRI and fusion biopsy every year or two. Would like to move past this if I can in one way or another. Fearful of positive margins etc. Was unfamiliar with this procedure so was not prepared with adequate questions.

Posts.Title: My Story and decision time

Posts.Content: Thank you for the replies. I am emailing the surgeon to tell him I want a complete removal of my prostate rather than partial. Having thought about it seems to be the correct choice. I don't want to deal with more scans, biopsies or further surgeries in the future. As for incontinence issues there some men on forums that have permanent serious problems that have never improved. They are troubling to read and makes me wonder if I making the correct choice but the cancer has to go away and I don't think their really is another choice. Hopefully the are the minority rather than the majority but I guess it is what it is. Try to prepare for the worst and hope for the best. Thanks again for your replies and concern.
Posts.Title: My Story and decision time

Posts.Content: Thank you for the replies. I am emailing the surgeon to tell him I want a complete removal of my prostate rather than partial. Having thought about it seems to be the correct choice. I don't want to deal with more scans, biopsies or further surgeries in the future. As for incontinence issues there some men on forums that have permanent serious problems that have never improved. They are troubling to read and makes me wonder if I making the correct choice but the cancer has to go away and I don't think their really is another choice. Hopefully the are the minority rather than the majority but I guess it is what it is. Try to prepare for the worst and hope for the best. Thanks again for your replies and concern.
Posts.Title: My Story and decision time

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi T3! ng = nanogram 1 nanogram = 1 x 10-9 gram Therefore: 0.001ng = 1 Trillionth of a Gram For this reason we "suggest" that one pays no attention to the 3rd decimal point in a uPSA value! Simply round off to the 2nd decimal point. MF Yes, sorry determined that after the post. Can't help but think there would be a lot of lab fluctuations at that level.
Posts.Title: New Math?

Posts.Content: This is part of an article from John Hopkins Univ. Interesting take on fluctuations of psa tests. PSA Anxiety: The Downside of Ultra- Sensitive Tests You've had the radical prostatectomy, but deep down, you're terrified that it didn't work. So here you are, a grown man, living in fear of a simple blood test, scared to death that the PSA- an enzyme made only by prostate cells, but all of your prostate cells are supposed to be gone -- will come back. Six months ago, the number was 0.01. This time, it was 0.02. You have PSA anxiety. You are not alone. This is the bane of the hypersensitive PSA test: Sometimes, there is such a thing as too much information. Daniel W Chan, Ph.D., is professor of pathology, oncology, urology and radiology, and Director of Clinical Chemistry at Hopkins. He is also an internationally recognized authority on biochemical tumor markers such as PSA, and on immunoassay tests such as the PSA test. This is some of what he has to say on the subject of PSA anxiety: The only thing that really matters, he says, is: "At what PSA levels does the concentration indicate that the patient has had a recurrence of cancer?" For Chan, and the scientists and physicians at Hopkins, the number to take seriously is 0.2 nanograms/milliliter. "That's something we call biochemical recurrence. But even this doesn't mean that a man has symptoms yet. People need to understand that it might take months or even years before there is any clinical physical evidence." On a technical level, in the laboratory, Chan trusts the sensitivity of assays down to 0. 1, or slightly less than that. "You cannot reliably detect such a small amount as 0.01," he explains. "From day to day, the results could vary -- it could be 0.03, or maybe even 0.05" -- and these "analytical" variations may not mean a thing. "It's important that we don't assume anything or take action on a very low level of PSA. In routine practice, because of these analytical variations from day to day, if it's less than 0. 1, we assume it's the same as nondetectable, or zero."
Posts.Title: Psa fluctuations after prostate removal

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH It's the same with Mayo Clinic. They usually use the standard PSA test and say uPSA causes too much unnecessary anxiety. Perhaps, in certain cases, they might us the uPSA, but mine have always been the standard test. I see that your psa has been <0.1 which is apparently the trigger point they still use from the original article as shown above. I would think it takes out the psa result wobble and only becomes a concern above 0.1. Makes more sense than chasing the 0.01 or 0.001 increases which are probably often meaningless and stressful for the patient.

Posts.Title: Psa fluctuations after prostate removal

Posts.Content: I keep reading posts on here about the ultrasensitive psa tests and them going to 3 decimal places such as .001. People refer to this result as a results in the trillionths. Unless they changed something in math(which they may have) 0.1 = 1 tenth, 0.01 = one hundredth and .001 = one thousandth. Where is everybody getting trillionths when they are stressing the extreme accuracy of the ultrasensitive psa tests and how good they are? I must be missing something. Thanks for clarifying and I hope all are well
Posts.Title: New Math?

Posts.Title: Psa fluctuations after prostate removal

Posts.Content: So in all the statistical studies do any of them address psa testing that has a bit of a wobble with results. so if you get a psa >0.03 at 3 months in reading these studies I would say I will deal with a BCR at some point in time. Do any of them take into account lab errors, calibration , dehydration etc into their statistical models? It seems like maybe they don't think they exist of perhaps they muddy the data and they are omitted? Or perhaps >0.03 is bad no matter what even if psa results goes down on the next test?
